[[Breakthrough Prize]] (2018) | thesis_title = Seshadri Constants of Ample Vector Bundles Divisors on Principally Polarized Abelian Varieties | thesis_year = 1998 }} '''Christopher Derek Hacon''' {{post-nominals|FRS}} (born 14 February 1970) is a [[mathematician]] with [[Great Britain|British]], Italian and US nationalities.As Hacon states in his [http://www.math.utah.edu/~hacon/cv.pdf Curriculum Vitae] He is currently distinguished professor of mathematics at the [[University of Utah]] where he holds a Presidential Endowed Chair. His research interests include [[algebraic geometry]]. Hacon was born in [[Manchester]], but grew up in [[Italy]] where he studied at the [[Scuola Normale Superiore]] and received a degree in mathematics at the [[University of Pisa]] in 1992. He received his [[doctorate]] from the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] in 1998, under supervision of [[Robert Lazarsfeld]]. ==Awards and honors== In 2007 he was awarded a Clay Research Award for his work, joint with [[James McKernan]], on "the birational geometry of algebraic varieties in dimension greater than three, in particular, for [an] inductive proof of the existence of flips." {{cite web|title=Clay Research Awards|url=http://www.claymath.org/research|publisher=[[Clay Mathematics Institute]]}} In 2009 he was awarded the [[Cole Prize]] for outstanding contribution to algebra, along with McKernan.{{cite web| url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200904/rtx090400494p.pdf| title=2009 Cole Prize in Algebra}} He was an invited speaker at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] 2010 in [[Hyderabad]], on the topic of "''Algebraic Geometry.''"{{cite web|title=ICM Plenary and Invited Speakers since 1897|url=http://www.mathunion.org/db/ICM/Speakers/SortedByCongress.php|publisher=[[International Congress of Mathematicians]]}} In 2011 he was awarded the [[Feltrinelli Prize|Antonio Feltrinelli Prize]] in Mathematics, Mechanics and Applications by Italy's prestigious [[Accademia dei Lincei|Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-01-19. In 2012 he became a [[Simons Investigator]].[https://www.simonsfoundation.org/mathematics-physical-sciences/simons-investigators/simons-investigators-awardees/ Simons Investigators Awardees], The Simons Foundation In 2015 he won the American Mathematical Society Moore Prize.[http://www.ams.org/profession/prizes-awards/ams-prizes/moore-prize AMS Moore Prize], retrieved 2015-12-01. In 2017 he was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.[https://www.amacad.org/content/members/newFellows.aspx?s=a 2017 Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences], retrieved 2017-12-1. In 2017 he won the 2018 [[Breakthrough Prize in Mathematics]] (with [[James McKernan]]).[https://breakthroughprize.org/Laureates/3/L3817 Breakthrough Prize], retrieved 2017-4-12. In 2018 he was elected to the [[National Academy of Sciences]]. In 2019, he was elected to the [[Royal Society]].{{cite web |title=Distinguished scientists elected as Fellows and Foreign Members of the Royal Society {{!}} Royal Society |url=https://royalsociety.org/news/2019/04/royal-society-announces-2019-fellows/ |website=royalsociety.org |accessdate=18 April 2019 |language=en-gb}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{MathGenealogy |id=36635}} * [http://www.math.utah.edu/~hacon/ Website of University of Utah] {{Breakthrough Prize laureates}} {{FRS 2019}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hacon, Christopher}} [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:20th-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century Italian mathematicians]] [[Category:Italian mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century Italian mathematicians]] [[Category:University of Utah faculty]] [[Category:Clay Research Award recipients]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:University of Pisa alumni]] [[Category:Simons Investigator]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] {{mathematician-stub}}

'''Georges Henri Halphen''' (30 October 1844, [[Rouen]] – 23 May 1889, [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]) was a [[French people|French]] [[mathematician]]. He did his studies at [[École Polytechnique]] (X 1862). He was known for his work in [[geometry]], particularly in [[enumerative geometry]] and the [[singularity theory]] of [[algebraic curve]]s, in [[algebraic geometry]]. He also worked on [[invariant theory]] and [[projective differential geometry]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Cajori, Florian | authorlink=Florian Cajori |title=A History of Mathematics| location=New York | publisher=Chelsea | year=1991 | isbn=0-8218-2102-4}} (org. published by [[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]], 1919)</ref>

==Biography==
In 1872 he married Rose Marguerite Aron, with whom he had eight children, four sons and four daughters. Of the four sons, three joined the military and two of them died in World War I. One of his grandsons was Étienne Halphen (1911–1954), who did significant work in applied statistics.<ref>[http://www1.alliancefr.com/les-juifs-de-picardie-news40,42,4559.html Les Juifs de Picardie]</ref>

==Awards==
Georges Henri Halphen received in the Steiner prize of the Prussian Academy of Sciences in 1880 along with [[Max Noether]]. In 1881 Halphen received the grand prize of the ''[[Académie des sciences (France)|Académie des sciences]]'' for his work on linear differential equations ''Mémoire sur la Reduction des Equations Différentielles Linéaires aux Formes Intégrales''. He received the [[Poncelet Prize|''prix Poncelet'']] in 1883<ref>{{cite book|chapter=Prix|title=Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des sciences|year=1900|page=1570|location=Paris|publisher=Gauthier-Villars|volume=Tomes XCII à CXXI, 3 Janvier 1881 à 30 Décembre 1895|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y94PAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1570}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Prizes given by the French Academy|journal=The American Naturalist|year=1884|volume=18|issue=7|page=751|doi=10.1086/273730|publisher=U. of Chicago Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2KtLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA751}}</ref> and the ''prix d'Ormoy'' in 1885. He was elected to  the ''Académie des sciences'' in 1886 in the ''Section de Géométrie'', replacing the deceased [[Jean Claude Bouquet]].<ref>[[Émile Picard]], [http://www.academie-sciences.fr/activite/archive/dossiers/Picard/Picard_pdf/Picard_Halphen.pdf Notice sur la vie et les travaux de Georges-Henri Halphen]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Comptes rendus de l'Académie des sciences|CRAS]], 1890</ref> In 1887 Halphen was elected to the [[Accademia dei Lincei]] in Rome.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Poincaré, Henri|authorlink=Henri Poincaré|title=Notice sur Halphen|journal=Journal de l'École polytechnique|year=1890|volume=60|pages=137–161}}</ref>

==Works==
* ''Oeuvres'', in 4 vols. edited by [[Camille Jordan]], [[Henri Poincaré]], [[Charles Émile Picard]] with assistance from [[Ernest Vessiot]], 1916, 1918,<ref>{{cite journal|author=Carmichael, R. D.|authorlink=Robert Daniel Carmichael|title=Review: C. Jordan, H. Poincaré, É. Picard, and E. Vessiot, ''Oeuvres de G. H. Halphen'' (Tomes I, II)|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1921|volume=27|issue=9–10|pages=466–469|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1921-27-09/S0002-9904-1921-03474-4/|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1921-03474-4}}</ref> 1921,<ref>{{cite journal|author=Carmichael, R. D.|title=Review: C. Jordan, H. Poincaré, É. Picard, and E. Vessiot, ''Oeuvres de G. H. Halphen'' (Tome III)|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1922|volume=28|issue=5|pages=271–272|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1922-28-05/S0002-9904-1922-03546-X/|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1922-03546-X}}</ref> 1924,<ref>{{cite journal|author=Carmichael, R. D.|title=Review: C. Jordan, H. Poincaré, É. Picard, and E. Vessiot, ''Oeuvres de G. H. Halphen'' (Tome IV)|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|year=1925|volume=31|issue=9|pages=562–563|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1925-31-09/S0002-9904-1925-04120-8/|doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1925-04120-8}}</ref> Gauthier-Villars
* ''Traité des fonctions elliptiques et de leurs applications'', 3 vols., 1886, 1888, 1891 (in vol. 2 applications to physics, geometry, the theory of integrals, and geodesy; in vol. 3 applications to algebra, especially the quintic equation, number theory — vol. 3 consists merely of fragments)

==Sources==

[[File:Megumi Harada.jpg|thumb|Megumi Harada]]
'''Megumi Harada''' is a mathematician who works as a professor in the department of mathematics and statistics at [[McMaster University]], where she holds a tier-two [[Canada Research Chair]] in Equivariant Symplectic and Algebraic Geometry.{{r|mcmf|3crc}}

==Research==
Harada's research involves the symmetries of [[symplectic geometry|symplectic spaces]] and their connections to other areas of mathematics including [[algebraic geometry]], [[representation theory]], [[K-theory|''K''-theory]], and [[algebraic combinatorics]].{{r|michler}}

==Education and career==
Harada graduated in 1996 from [[Harvard University]], with a bachelor's degree in mathematics.{{r|michler}} She completed her doctorate in 2003 from the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. Her dissertation, ''The Symplectic Geometry of the Gel'fand-Cetlin-Molev Basis for Representations of Sp(2n, C)'', concerned [[symplectic geometry]] and was supervised by [[Allen Knutson]].{{r|michler|mgp}}

After postdoctoral studies at the [[University of Toronto]], she joined the McMaster faculty in 2006.{{r|michler}}

==Recognition==
In 2013, Harada won the Ruth I. Michler Memorial Prize of the [[Association for Women in Mathematics]], funding her travel to [[Cornell University]] for research collaborations with Reyer Sjamar, [[Tara S. Holm]], and Allen Knutson.{{r|michler}} She was given her Canada Research Chair in 2014.{{r|3crc}} She is the 2018 winner of the [[Krieger–Nelson Prize]] "for her research on Newton–Okounkov bodies, Hessenberg varieties, and their relationships to symplectic geometry, combinatorics, and equivariant topology, among others".{{r|kn}}

'''Joseph Daniel Harris''' (born August 17, 1951), known nearly universally as Joe Harris, is a [[mathematician]] at [[Harvard University]] working in the field of [[algebraic geometry]].  He attended [[college]] at and received his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1978 under [[Phillip Griffiths]].

==Work==
During the 1980s he was on the faculty of [[Brown University]], moving to Harvard around 1988{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}.  He served as chair of the department at Harvard from 2002 to 2005.  His work is characterized by its classical geometric flavor: he has claimed that nothing he thinks about could not have been imagined by the [[Italian geometers]] of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and that if he has had greater success than them, it is because he has access to better tools.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}

Harris is well known for several of his books on algebraic geometry, notable for their informal presentations:
* ''Principles of Algebraic Geometry'' {{ISBN|978-0-471-05059-9}}, with Phillip Griffiths<ref>{{cite journal|author=Lipman, Joseph|title=Review: ''Principles of algebraic geometry'', by Phillip Godwin, and Joseph Harris|year=1980|volume=2|issue=1|pages=197–200|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1980-02-01/S0273-0979-1980-14717-5/S0273-0979-1980-14717-5.pdf|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-1980-14717-5}}</ref>
* ''Geometry of Algebraic Curves, Vol. 1'' {{ISBN|978-0-387-90997-4}}, with [[Enrico Arbarello]], [[Maurizio Cornalba]], and Phillip Griffiths
* {{Citation | title=Representation Theory, A First Course | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | series=[[Graduate Texts in Mathematics]] | isbn=978-0-387-97495-8 |mr=1153249 | year=1991 | volume=129 | author=William Fulton, Joe Harris. | doi=10.1007/978-1-4612-0979-9}}, with [[William Fulton (mathematician)|William Fulton]]
* {{Citation | title=Algebraic Geometry: A First Course | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | isbn=978-0-387-97716-4 | year=1995 | author=Joe Harris.}}
* {{Citation | title=The Geometry of Schemes | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | series=Graduate Texts in Mathematics | isbn=978-0-387-98638-8 |mr=1730819 | year=2000 | volume=197 | author=David Eisenbud, Joe Harris.}}, with [[David Eisenbud]]
*{{cite book| title=3264 and All That: A Second Course in Algebraic Geometry|author=[[David Eisenbud]], [[Joe Harris (mathematician)|Joseph Harris]] (2016)|publisher= [[Cambridge University Press]]| isbn=978-1107602724|}}
* ''Moduli of Curves'' {{ISBN|978-0-387-98438-4}}, with [[Ian Morrison (mathematician)|Ian Morrison]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ciliberto, Ciro|title=Review: ''Moduli of curves'', by J. Harris and I. Morrison|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|year=1999|volume=36|issue=4|pages=499–503|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/1999-36-04/S0273-0979-99-00791-0/S0273-0979-99-00791-0.pdf|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-99-00791-0}}</ref>

Harris has supervised 50 Ph.D. students (as of 2018), including [[Brendan Hassett]], [[James McKernan]], [[Rahul Pandharipande]], [[Zvezdelina Stankova]] and [[Ravi Vakil]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=18748|title=Joseph Harris - The Mathematics Genealogy Project|website=www.genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref>

[[Arthur Ogus]] | known_for = | awards = [[Leroy P. Steele Prize|Steele Prize]] (1979) }} ''' Robin Cope Hartshorne''' (born March 15, 1938) is an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]]. Hartshorne is an [[algebraic geometry|algebraic geometer]] who studied with [[Oscar Zariski]], [[David Mumford]], [[Jean-Pierre Serre]] and [[Alexander Grothendieck]]. He was a [[William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition|Putnam Fellow]] in Fall, 1958. He received his [[doctorate]] from [[Princeton University]] in 1963{{MathGenealogy|id=29466}} and then became a [[Junior Fellow]] at [[Harvard University]], where he taught for several years. In the 1970s he was appointed to the faculty at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He is currently{{when?|date=February 2018}} retired. Hartshorne is the author of the text ''[[Algebraic Geometry (book)|Algebraic Geometry]]''. In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-01-19. ==Selected publications== *''Foundations of Projective Geometry'', New York: W. pages.title: Brendan Hassett
pages.text:
'''Brendan Edward Hassett''' is an American mathematician who works as a professor of mathematics at [[Brown University]].<ref name="cv">[http://math.brown.edu/~bhassett/cv/currcv.pdf Curriculum vitae] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724033304/http://www.math.brown.edu/~bhassett/cv/currcv.pdf |date=2015-07-24 }}, retrieved 2015-02-11.</ref> His research interests include [[algebraic geometry]] and [[number theory]].

Hassett graduated from [[Yale University|Yale College]] in 1992,<ref name="cv"/> and earned his doctorate in 1996 from [[Harvard University]] under the supervision of [[Joe Harris (mathematician)|Joe Harris]].<ref name="cv"/><ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=42398}}</ref> After temporary positions at the [[Mittag-Leffler Institute]], [[University of Chicago]], and [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]], he joined the [[Rice University]] faculty in 2000. He was promoted to full professor in 2006, chaired the department from 2009 to 2014, and was named as the Milton Brockett Porter Professor of Mathematics in 2013. In July 2015 he moved to [[Brown University]].<ref name="cv"/>  He is currently the Director of the [[Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics]].

Hassett is the author of the textbook ''Introduction to Algebraic Geometry'' (Cambridge University Press, 2007).<ref>Review of ''Introduction to Algebraic Geometry'' by D.-M. Popescu (2008), {{MR|2324354}}</ref><ref>[http://www.maa.org/publications/maa-reviews/introduction-to-algebraic-geometry-0 Review of ''Introduction to Algebraic Geometry''] by P. N. Ruane (June 9, 2008), MAA Reviews, [[Mathematical Association of America]], retrieved 2015-02-11.</ref>

In 2013, Hassett was named as a [[fellow]] of the [[American Mathematical Society]] "for contributions to higher-dimensional arithmetic geometry and birational geometry."<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]</ref>

[[University of Cambridge]] (PhD) {{MathGenealogy|id=49356|name=Tamás Hausel}} |doctoral_advisor = [[Nigel James Hitchin]]  |awards = [[Whitehead Prize]] {{small|(2008)}} }} '''Tamás Hausel''' (born 1972) is a Hungarian mathematician working in the areas of [[combinatorial geometry|combinatorial]], [[differential geometry|differential]] and [[algebraic geometry]] and [[topology]].{{cite web|url=http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/~hausel/main.html|title=Homepage|author=Tamás Hausel|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719122452/http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/~hausel/main.html|archivedate=2011-07-19|df=}} More specifically the [[global analysis]], geometry, topology and arithmetic of [[hyperkähler manifold]]s, [[Yang–Mills instanton]]s, non-Abelian [[Hodge theory]], [[Geometric Langlands program]], and [[representation theory]] of [[Quiver (mathematics)|quiver]]s and [[Kac–Moody algebra]]s.{{cite web|url=https://www1.maths.ox.ac.uk/ldapcontact/userdetails/hausel|title=Dr Tamás Hausel|author=Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford}} Tamás Hausel is currently associated with [[IST Austria]] where he is a full professor since 2016. Prior to joining [[Institute of Science and Technology, Austria|IST]] he was a professor at [[EPFL]].He was previously at the [[University of Oxford]], both a [[Royal Society]] University [[Research Fellow]] at the university's mathematical institute, and a Tutorial Fellow in Mathematics at [[Wadham College, Oxford|Wadham College]]. == Awards == In 2008, Tamás Hausel was awarded the [[Whitehead Prize]] by the [[London Mathematical Society]] for his investigations into hyperkähler geometry which have led him to prove deep results in fields as diverse as the representation theory of quivers, mirror symmetry and Yang–Mills instantons.{{cite web|url=http://www.lms.ac.uk/activities/prizes_com/citations08.html|title=Prize Winners 2008|author=London Mathematical Society}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} == Publications == *{{cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=333845&Submit=Search|title=MathSciNet|accessdate=October 31, 2010}} *{{cite web|url=https://arxiv.org/find/math/1/au:+Hausel_T/0/1/0/all/0/1|title=ArXiv|accessdate=October 31, 2010}} *{{cite web|url=http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/~hausel/publication|title=Publication List|author=Tamás Hausel|accessdate=October 31, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719123127/http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/~hausel/publication/|archivedate=July 19, 2011|df=}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hausel, Tamas}} [[Category:Academics of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Differential geometers]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Hungarian mathematicians]] [[Category:Whitehead Prize winners]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge]]

[[Legion of Honour]] {{small|(2004)}} }} {{nihongo|'''Heisuke Hironaka'''|広中 平祐|Hironaka Heisuke|extra=born April 9, 1931}} is a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[mathematician]]. He entered [[Kyoto University]] in 1949. After completing his undergraduate studies at [[Kyoto University]], he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in 1960 from [[Harvard]] while under the direction of [[Oscar Zariski]].{{cite magazine|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2011/05/centennial-medalists|title=Meet the 2011 Centennial Medalists|magazine=[[Harvard Magazine]]|accessdate=March 10, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/alumni/centennial_medal_2011.php |title=GSAS ALUMNI |publisher=[[Harvard College]] |accessdate=March 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212092957/http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/alumni/centennial_medal_2011.php |archivedate=February 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} He was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1970.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyoto-u.ac.jp/en/profile/intro/honor/fields.htm/|title=Fields Medallists|publisher=[[Kyoto University]]|accessdate=March 10, 2014}} He is celebrated for proving in 1964 that [[singular point of an algebraic variety|singularities of algebraic varieties]] admit [[resolution of singularities|resolutions]] in characteristic zero.{{Citation|last=Hironaka|first=Heisuke|year=1964|title=Resolution of Singularities of an Algebraic Variety Over a Field of Characteristic Zero: I|journal=Annals of Mathematics|volume=79|pages=109–203|jstor=1970486|doi=10.2307/1970486}} This means that any [[algebraic variety]] can be replaced by (more precisely is [[birational equivalence|birationally equivalent]] to) a similar variety which has no singularities. He also introduced [[Hironaka's example]] showing that a deformation of [[Kähler manifold]]s need not be Kähler.{{Citation|last=Hironaka|first=Heisuke|year=1962|title=An example of a non-Kählerian complex-analytic deformation of Kählerian complex structures.|journal=Annals of Mathematics|volume=75|pages=190–208|jstor=1970426|doi=10.2307/1970426}} In 2017 he posted to his personal webpage a manuscript that claims to prove the existence of a resolution of singularities in positive characteristic.{{cite web|url=http://www.math.harvard.edu/~hironaka/pRes.pdf|title=Resolution of singularities in positive characteristics|publisher=[[Harvard University]]|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} Hironaka was for many years a Professor of mathematics at [[Harvard University]] (1968-1992) but currently lives in [[Japan]]. He held teaching positions at [[Brandeis University]] (1960-1963), [[Columbia University]] (1964) and [[Kyoto University]] (1975-1988).{{cite web|url=http://www.kurims.kyoto-u.ac.jp/en/emeritus.html|title=Professor Emeritus|publisher=[[Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences]], [[Kyoto University]]|accessdate=March 10, 2014}} He was a president of [[Yamaguchi University]] (1996-2002).{{cite web|url=http://www.yamaguchi-u.ac.jp/english/17/66.html |title=Former President of Yamaguchi University |publisher=[[Yamaguchi University]] |accessdate=March 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310070409/http://www.yamaguchi-u.ac.jp/english/17/66.html |archivedate=March 10, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} He has been active in raising funds for causes such as mathematical education. His daughter, Eriko Hironaka, is also a mathematician and focuses on [[low-dimensional topology]] and [[geometric topology]].https://www.math.fsu.edu/~hironaka/Vita/vita2016.pdf == List of books available in English == * ''Formal functions and formal imbeddings'' / by Heisuke Hironaka and Hideyuki Matsumura (1967) * ''On the characters \nu and \tau of singularities'' / by Heisuke Hironaka * ''Introduction to the theory of infinitely near singular points'' / Heisuke Hironaka (1974) * ''The theory of the maximal contact'' / José M. Aroca, Heisuke Hironaka and José L. Vicente (1975) * ''Desingularization theorems'' / Jose M. Aroca, Heisuke Hironaka and Jose L. Vicente (1977) * ''Geometric singularity theory'' / editors of the volume, Heisuke Hironaka, Stanisław Janeczko (2004) ==See also== *[[Hironaka decomposition]] *[[Hironaka's criterion]] *[[René Thom]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{MathGenealogy |id=18752}} * {{MacTutor Biography|id=Hironaka}} * Jackson, Allyn; [http://www.ams.org/notices/200509/fea-hironaka.pdf Interview with Heisuke Hironaka]; ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society''; vol. 52, no. 9 (October 2005). {{Fields medalists}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hironaka, Heisuke}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:20th-century Japanese mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century Japanese mathematicians]] [[Category:Algebraic geometers]] [[Category:Fields Medalists]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:Brandeis University faculty]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:Kyoto University alumni]] [[Category:Kyoto University faculty]] [[Category:Institute for Advanced Study visiting scholars]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the French Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Foreign Members of the Russian Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Spouses of Japanese politicians]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Culture]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]]

'''Friedrich Ernst Peter Hirzebruch''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|ForMemRS]]<ref name="frs"/> (17 October 1927 – 27 May 2012) was a [[Germans|German]] [[mathematician]], working in the fields of [[topology]], [[complex manifold]]s and [[algebraic geometry]], and a leading figure in his generation. He has been described as "the most important mathematician in Germany of the postwar period."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.math.columbia.edu/~woit/wordpress/?p=4723|title=Friedrich Hirzebruch 1927-2012|date=29 May 2012|accessdate=29 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Europa Publications |title=The International Who's Who 2004 |publisher=Routledge |year=2003 |isbn=978-1-85743-217-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=neKm1X6YPY0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+International+Who%27s+Who+2004&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%22Hirzebruch%2C%20Friedrich%22&f=false |accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Hirzebruch | first1=Friedrich | author1-link=Friedrich Hirzebruch | last2=Mayer | first2=Karl Heinz | title=O(n)-Mannigfaltigkeiten, Exotische Sphären und Singularitäten | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics | doi=10.1007/BFb0074355 | mr=0229251  | year=1968 | volume=57}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Hirzebruch | first1=Friedrich | author1-link=Friedrich Hirzebruch | last2=Zagier | first2=Don | title=The Atiyah-Singer theorem and elementary number theory | publisher=Publish or Perish | location=Houston, TX | mr=0650832  | year=1974}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Hirzebruch | first1=Friedrich | author1-link=Friedrich Hirzebruch | title=Gesammelte Abhandlungen. Band I, II | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gHOL7cNOzD4C | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | isbn=978-3-540-18087-6 | mr=931775  | year=1987}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Hirzebruch | first1=Friedrich | author1-link=Friedrich Hirzebruch | last2=Jung | first2=Rainer | last3=Berger | first3=Thomas | title=Manifolds and modular forms | publisher=Friedr. Vieweg & Sohn | location=Braunschweig | series=Aspects of Mathematics, E20 | isbn=978-3-528-06414-3 | mr=1189136  | year=1992}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Hirzebruch | first1=Friedrich | author1-link=Friedrich Hirzebruch | title=Topological methods in algebraic geometry | origyear=1956 | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | location=Berlin, New York | series=Classics in Mathematics | isbn=978-3-540-58663-0 | mr=1335917  | year=1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Segel|first=Joel|title=Friedrich Hirzebruch: Giant of German Mathematics|url=https://simonsfoundation.org/mps-science-lives/-/asset_publisher/bo1E/content/friedrich-hirzebruch-giant-of-german-mathematics?redirect=%2Fmps-science-lives|date=2011-12-01|publisher=Simons Foundation}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1=Atiyah | first1=Michael | last2=Zagier | first2=Don |  title=Friedrich Hirzebruch (1927–2012) | url=http://www.ams.org/notices/201407/rnoti-p706.pdf | year=2014 | journal=[[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]] | volume=61 | issue=7 | pages=706–727 | doi=10.1090/noti1145}}</ref>

==Education==
Hirzebruch was born in [[Hamm]], [[Province of Westphalia|Westphalia]] in 1927.<ref name="mactutor">{{MacTutor|id=Hirzebruch|title=Friedrich Hirzebruch}}</ref> 
His father of the same name was a math teacher.
Hirzebruch studied at the [[University of Münster]] from 1945–1950, with one year at [[ETH Zürich]].

==Career==
Hirzebruch then held a position at [[University of Erlangen-Nuremberg|Erlangen]], followed by the years 1952–54 at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]]. After one year at [[Princeton University]] 1955–56, he was made a professor at the [[University of Bonn]], where he remained, becoming director of the ''[[Max-Planck-Institut für Mathematik]]'' in 1981.  
More than 300 people gathered in celebration of his 80th birthday in Bonn in 2007.

The [[Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch theorem]] (1954) for [[complex manifolds]] was a major advance and quickly became part of the mainstream developments around the classical [[Riemann–Roch theorem]]; 
it was also a precursor of the [[Atiyah–Singer index theorem]]. 
Hirzebruch's book ''Neue topologische Methoden in der algebraischen Geometrie'' (1956) was a basic text for the 'new methods' of [[sheaf theory]], in [[complex algebraic geometry]]. 
He went on to write the foundational papers on topological [[K-theory]] with [[Michael Atiyah]], and collaborate with [[Armand Borel]] on the theory of [[characteristic class]]es.  In his later work he provided a detailed theory of [[Hilbert modular surface]]s, working with [[Don Zagier]].

In March 1945, Hirzebruch became a soldier, and in April, in the last weeks of Hitler's rule, he was taken prisoner by the British forces then invading Germany from the west.  When a British soldier found that he was studying mathematics, he drove him home and released him, and told him to continue studying.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20160304093533/http://pyrrho.wsc.ma.edu/math/faculty/fleron/quotes/viewquote.asp?letter=h</ref>

Hirzebruch died at the age of 84 on 27 May 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mpim-bonn.mpg.de/|title=With great sadness we mourn the death of our founder, Friedrich Hirzebruch, who passed away on Sunday, May 27|work=Max Planck Institute for Mathematics}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mpim-bonn.mpg.de/ Max Planck Institute Announcement], [[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]]. Retrieved on 29 May 2012.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/11/world/europe/friedrich-hirzebruch-mathematician-dies.html "Friedrich Hirzebruch, Mathematician, Is Dead at 84"]</ref>

==Honours and awards==
Amongst many other honours, Hirzebruch was awarded a [[Wolf Prize in Mathematics]] in 1988 and a [[Lobachevsky Medal]] in 1989.<ref name=schecter>{{citation |last=Schecter |first=Bruce |title=Friedrich Hirzebruch, Mathematician, Is Dead at 84 | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 10, 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/11/world/europe/friedrich-hirzebruch-mathematician-dies.html}}</ref>

The government of [[Japan]] awarded him the [[Order of the Sacred Treasure]] in 1996.<ref>[http://www.editions-harmattan.fr/index.asp?navig=catalogue&obj=article&no=8245 L'Harmattan web site (in French)], Order with gold and silver rays</ref>

Hirzebruch won an [[Einstein Medal]] in 1999, and received the [[Cantor medal]] in 2004.

Hirzebruch was a foreign member of numerous academies and societies, including the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]], the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], the [[Royal Society]]<ref name="frs"/> and the [[French Academy of Sciences]]. 
In 1980–81 he delivered the first [[Sackler Distinguished Lectures|Sackler Distinguished Lecture]] in [[Israel]].

pages.title: Hoàng Xuân Sính
pages.text:
'''Hoàng Xuân Sính''' (born September 8, 1933)<ref>Birth date from [http://www.isni.org/isni/0000000006540623 ISNI authority control file], retrieved 2018-11-28.</ref> is a [[Vietnam]]ese mathematician, a student of [[Alexander Grothendieck|Grothendieck]], the first female mathematician in Vietnam, the founder of Thang Long University, and the recipient of the ''[[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]]''.

==Early life and career==
Hoàng was born in Cót, in the [[Từ Liêm District]] of Vietnam, one of seven children of fabric merchant Hoàng Thuc Tan. Her mother died when she was eight years old, and she was raised by a stepmother. She has also frequently been said to be the granddaughter of Vietnamese mathematician [[Hoàng Xuân Hãn]]. She completed a bachelor's degree in 1951 in Hanoi, studying English and French, and then traveled to Paris for a second baccalaureate in mathematics.<ref>{{citation|title=Story house first female mathematician in Vietnam|url=http://antg.cand.com.vn/Phong-su/Chuyen-nha-nu-toan-hoc-dau-tien-o-Viet-Nam-295223/|publisher=An ninh thé giói|language=Vietnamese|date=August 14, 2009}}.</ref> She stayed in France to study for an ''[[agrégation]]'' at the [[University of Toulouse]], which she completed in 1959, before returning to Vietnam to become a mathematics teacher at the [[Hanoi National University of Education]].<ref name="tintuc"/> Hoàng became the first female mathematician in Vietnam<ref name="tintuc"/> and at that time was one of a very small number of mathematicians there with a foreign education.<ref name="koblitz">{{citation|title=Random Curves: Journeys of a Mathematician|first=Neal|last=Koblitz|authorlink=Neal Koblitz|publisher=Springer|year=2009|isbn=9783540740780|page=165|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QalcsaNtIC&pg=PA165}}.</ref>

==Work with Grothendieck==
The French mathematician and pacifist [[Alexander Grothendieck]] visited North Vietnam in late 1967, during the [[Vietnam War]], and spent a month teaching mathematics to the Hanoi University mathematics department staff,<ref name="remembering"/> including Hoàng, who took the notes for the lectures.<ref name="koblitz"/> Because of the war, Grothendieck's lectures were held away from Hanoi, first in the nearby countryside and later in [[Đại Từ]]. After Grothendieck returned to France, he continued to teach Hoàng as a correspondence student.<ref name="remembering">[http://en.thanglong.edu.vn/news-and-events/1209-remembering-alexandre-grothendieck Remembering Alexandre Grothendieck], Thang Long University, November 18, 2014, accessed 2015-07-18.</ref> She earned her doctorate under Grothendieck's supervision from [[Paris Diderot University]] in 1975, with a handwritten thesis.<ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=105948}}</ref><ref>[http://w5.mathematik.uni-stuttgart.de/fachbereich/Kuenzer/Kuenzer/sinh.html Thesis of Hoàng Xuân Sính], Univ. of Stuttgart, retrieved 2015-07-18.</ref> Her thesis research, on algebraic structures based on [[category theory|categorical]] [[group (mathematics)|groups]] but with a group law that holds only up to isomorphism, prefigured much of the modern theory of [[2-group]]s.<ref>{{citation
 | last1 = Baez | first1 = John C. | author1-link = John C. Baez
 | last2 = Lauda | first2 = Aaron D.
 | journal = Theory and Applications of Categories
 | mr = 2068521
 | pages = 423–491
 | title = Higher-dimensional algebra. V. 2-groups
 | url = http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/hda5.pdf
 | volume = 12
 | year = 2004| bibcode = 2003math......7200B | arxiv = math/0307200 }}.</ref>

==Later accomplishments==
When she was promoted to full professor Hoàng became the first female full professor in Vietnam in any scientific or technical field.<ref>{{citation
 | last = Koblitz | first = Ann Hibner
 | editor1-last = Van Brummelen | editor1-first = Glen
 | editor2-last = Kinyon | editor2-first = Michael
 | contribution = Mathematics and gender: Some cross-cultural observations
 | doi = 10.1007/0-387-28272-6_13
 | pages = 329–345
 | publisher = Springer
 | series = CMS Books in Mathematics
 | title = Mathematics and the Historian's Craft
 | year = 2005}}. See in particular p. 330.</ref> In 1988 she founded the first private university in Vietnam, [[Thang Long University]] in Hanoi,<ref>{{citation
 | last = Fry | first = Gerald W.
 | editor1-last = Hirosato | editor1-first = Yasushi
 | editor2-last = Kitamura | editor2-first = Yuto
 | contribution = Higher education in Vietnam
 | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4020-9377-7_14
 | isbn = 9781402093777
 | pages = 237–261
 | publisher = Springer
 | series = Education in the Asia-Pacific Region: Issues, Concerns and Prospects
 | title = The Political Economy of Educational Reforms and Capacity Development in Southeast Asia: Cases of Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam
 | volume = 13
 | year = 2009}}. See in particular [https://books.google.com/books?id=aJek5arAW9MC&pg=PA246 p. 246].</ref> and became the president of its board of directors.<ref name="tintuc">{{citation|work=tintuc.vn|url=http://tintuc.vn/giao-duc/giao-su-tien-si-nha-giao-nhan-dan-hoang-xuan-sinh-nguoi-vinh-danh-viet-nam-tren-dat-phap-9215|title=Professor, PhD, People's Teacher Hoang Xuan Sinh: The Vietnam honored in France|language=Vietnamese|date=November 17, 2014}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.thanglong.edu.vn/gioi-thieu/gioi-thieu-chung/33-bai-phat-bi-u-c-a-co-hoang-xuan-sinh-t-i-l-k-ni-m-20-nam-thanh-l-p-tru-ng|title=Twenty years of Thang Long University (12/15/1988 - 15/12/2008): Speech by Professor Hoang Xuan Sinh, Chairman of the Board, at the ceremony of 20th anniversary of establishment of School|last=Hoàng|first= Xuân Sính|publisher=Thang Long University|language=Vietnamese|accessdate=2015-07-18}}.</ref>

==Recognition==

F. | authorlink = Michael Atiyah| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1976.0007 | title = William Vallance Douglas Hodge. 17 June 1903 -- 7 July 1975 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 22 | pages = 169–192| year = 1976 | pmid = | pmc = }} ({{IPAc-en|h|ɒ|dʒ}}; 17 June 1903 – 7 July 1975) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] mathematician, specifically a [[geometer]].{{MacTutor Biography|id=Hodge}}{{MathGenealogy |id=18583}} His discovery of far-reaching topological relations between [[algebraic geometry]] and [[differential geometry]]—an area now called [[Hodge theory]] and pertaining more generally to [[Kähler manifold]]s—has been a major influence on subsequent work in geometry. ==Life and career== He was born in [[Edinburgh]] in 1903, the son of Archibald James Hodge, searcher of public records, and his wife, Jane Vallance.{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}} They lived at 1 Church Hill Place in the [[Morningside, Edinburgh|Morningside]] district.Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1903-4 He attended [[George Watson's College]], and studied at [[Edinburgh University]], graduating MA in 1923. With help from [[E. T. Whittaker]], whose son [[J. M. Whittaker]] was a college friend, he then took the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]]. At Cambridge he fell under the influence of the geometer [[H. F. Baker]]. He gained a second MA in 1925. In 1926 he took up a teaching position at the [[University of Bristol]], and began work on the interface between the [[Italian school of algebraic geometry]], particularly problems posed by [[Francesco Severi]], and the topological methods of [[Solomon Lefschetz]]. This made his reputation, but led to some initial scepticism on the part of Lefschetz. According to Atiyah's memoir, Lefschetz and Hodge in 1931 had a meeting in [[Max Newman]]'s rooms in Cambridge, to try to resolve issues. In the end Lefschetz was convinced.{{Cite journal | last1 = Atiyah | first1 = M. F. | authorlink = Michael Atiyah| doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1976.0007 | title = William Vallance Douglas Hodge. 17 June 1903 -- 7 July 1975 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 22 | pages = 169–192| year = 1976 | pmid = | pmc = }} In 1928 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were Sir [[Edmund Taylor Whittaker]], [[Ralph Allan Sampson]], [[Charles Glover Barkla]], and Sir [[Charles Galton Darwin]]. He was awarded the Society's [[Gunning Victoria Jubilee Prize]] for the period 1964 to 1968.{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}} In 1930 Hodge was awarded a Research Fellowship at [[St. John's College, Cambridge]]. He spent a year 1931–2 at [[Princeton University]], where Lefschetz was, visiting also [[Oscar Zariski]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. At this time he was also assimilating [[de Rham's theorem]], and defining the [[Hodge star]] operation. It would allow him to define [[harmonic form]]s and so refine the de Rham theory. On his return to Cambridge, he was offered a University Lecturer position in 1933. He became the [[Lowndean Professor]] of Astronomy and Geometry at [[Cambridge]], a position he held from 1936 to 1970. He was the first head of [[Faculty of Mathematics, University of Cambridge|DPMMS]]. He was the Master of [[Pembroke College, Cambridge]] from 1958 to 1970, and vice-president of the [[Royal Society]] from 1959 to 1965. He was knighted in 1959. Amongst other honours, he received the [[Adams Prize]] in 1937 and the [[Copley Medal]] of the [[Royal Society]] in 1974. He died in [[Cambridge]] on 7 July 1975. ==Work== The [[Hodge index theorem]] was a result on the [[intersection number]] theory for curves on an [[algebraic surface]]: it determines the [[metric signature|signature]] of the corresponding [[quadratic form]]. This result was sought by the [[Italian school of algebraic geometry]], but was proved by the topological methods of [[Lefschetz]]. ''The Theory and Applications of Harmonic Integrals''{{cite journal|author=Struik, D. J.|author-link=Dirk Jan Struik|title=Review: W. V. D. Hodge, ''The theory and applications of harmonic integrals''|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|date=1944|volume=50|issue=1|pages=43–45|url=http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bams/1183505582|doi=10.1090/s0002-9904-1944-08054-3}} summed up Hodge's development during the 1930s of his general theory. This starts with the existence for any [[Kähler metric]] of a theory of [[Laplacian]]s – it applies to an [[algebraic variety]] V (assumed complex, projective and non-singular) because [[projective space]] itself carries such a metric. In [[de Rham cohomology]] terms, a cohomology class of degree ''k'' is represented by a ''k''-form α on V('''C'''). There is no unique representative; but by introducing the idea of ''harmonic form'' (Hodge still called them 'integrals'), which are solutions of [[Laplace's equation]], one can get unique α. This has the important, immediate consequence of splitting up :''H''''k''(V('''C'''), '''C''') into subspaces :''H''''p'',''q'' according to the number ''p'' of [[Holomorphic function|holomorphic]] differentials ''dzi'' wedged to make up α (the cotangent space being spanned by the ''dzi'' and their complex conjugates). The dimensions of the subspaces are the [[Hodge number]]s. This ''Hodge decomposition'' has become a fundamental tool. Not only do the dimensions h''p'',''q'' refine the [[Betti number]]s, by breaking them into parts with identifiable geometric meaning; but the decomposition itself, as a varying 'flag' in a complex vector space, has a meaning in relation with [[moduli problem]]s. In broad terms, Hodge theory contributes both to the discrete and the continuous classification of algebraic varieties. Further developments by others led in particular to an idea of [[mixed Hodge structure]] on singular varieties, and to deep analogies with [[étale cohomology]]. ==Hodge conjecture== The [[Hodge conjecture]] on the 'middle' spaces H''p'',''p'' is still unsolved, in general. It is one of the seven [[Millennium Prize Problems]] set up by the [[Clay Mathematics Institute]]. ==Exposition== Hodge also wrote, with [[Daniel Pedoe]], a three-volume work ''Methods of Algebraic Geometry'', on classical algebraic geometry, with much concrete content – illustrating though what [[Élie Cartan]] called 'the debauch of indices' in its component notation. According to [[Michael Atiyah|Atiyah]], this was intended to update and replace [[H. F. Baker]]'s ''Principles of Geometry''. ==Family== In 1929 he married Kathleen Anne Cameron.{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}} ==Publications== *{{Citation | last1=Hodge | first1=W. '''Geoffrey Horrocks''' (1932/33 [[Leicester]] - 12 September 2012) was a British mathematician working on [[vector bundle]]s, who introduced the [[Horrocks construction]] used in the [[ADHM construction]], and the [[Horrocks–Mumford bundle]] and [[Monad (linear algebra)|monads]].

He was a professor at [[Newcastle University]] until his retirement in 1998.

pages.title: June Huh
pages.text:
'''June Huh''' (born 1983) is a [[Korean Americans|Korean American]] mathematician. He is a Clay Research Fellow at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] and [[Princeton University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.math.princeton.edu/~huh/|title=June Huh's Home Page|website=web.math.princeton.edu|access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref>

Huh was born in [[California]] but grew up in [[South Korea]].<ref name="Quanta" /> He obtained his [[Ph.D.]] in 2014 from the [[University of Michigan]], with a thesis written under the direction of [[Mircea Mustaţă]].<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=185855}}</ref>

In joint work with [[Karim Adiprasito]] and [[Eric Katz]], he resolved the [[Heron–Rota–Welsh conjecture]] on the log-concavity of the [[characteristic polynomial of matroids]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gilkalai.wordpress.com/2015/08/14/updates-and-plans-iii/|title=Combinatorics and more}}</ref><ref name="Quanta">{{Cite news|url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/a-path-less-taken-to-the-peak-of-the-math-world-20170627/|title=A Path Less Taken to the Peak of the Math World |work=[[Quanta Magazine]]|access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref>
With Adiprasito, he is one of five winners of the 2019 New Horizons Prize for Early-Career Achievement in Mathematics, associated with the [[Breakthrough Prize in Mathematics]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://blogs.ams.org/beyondreviews/2018/10/18/break-on-through/|title=Break on Through|work=Beyond Reviews: Inside MathSciNet|first=Edward|last=Dunne|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|date=October 20, 2018}}</ref>

Huh was an [[List of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers#2018, Rio de Janeiro|invited speaker]] at the [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] in 2018 in [[Rio de Janeiro]].

'''Daniel Huybrechts''' (9 November 1966) is a German mathematician, specializing in algebraic geometry.<ref name="HuybrechtsHomepage">[http://www.math.uni-bonn.de/people/huybrech/ Huybrecht's homepage at the University of Bonn]</ref>

==Education and career==
Huybrechts studied mathematics from 1985 at the [[Humboldt University of Berlin]], where in 1989 he earned his [[Diplom]] with Diplom thesis supervisor Herbert Kurke. In 1990–1992 Huybrechts studied at the [[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]] in [[Bonn]], where he earned his Ph.D. (Promotion) in 1992 under Herbert Kurke with thesis ''Stabile Vektorbündel auf algebraischen Flächen. Tjurins Methode zum Studium der Geometrie der Modulräume''.<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=27565}}</ref> In the academic year 1994–1995 he was at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] and in 1996 at [[IHES]]. In 1996 he was a research assistant at the [[University of Essen]], where in 1998 he earned his Habilitierung. In 1997–1998 he was at the [[École normale supérieure]]. He was a professor in 1998–2002 at the University of Cologne and in 2002–2005 at the [[École polytechnique]] (Chargé de Cours) and, simultaneously, at the [[University of Paris VII]]. Since 2005 he has been a professor at the [[University of Bonn]].<ref name=HuybrechtsHomepage/>

Huybrechts does research on [[K3 surface]]s and their higher-dimensional analogues (compact hyperkähler manifolds) and moduli spaces of sheaves on varieties.

In 2010 he was an [[invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians]] in [[Hyderabad]] and gave a talk ''Hyperkähler Manifolds and Sheaves''.

* with [[Dominic Joyce]], Mark Gross: [https://books.google.com/books/about/Calabi_Yau_Manifolds_and_Related_Geometr.html?id=frKJmxAr2xUC ''Calabi-Yau manifolds and related geometries''], Springer 2002. 
* with Manfred Lehn: ''The geometry of moduli spaces of sheaves'', Vieweg, Aspects of Mathematics, 1997 {{cite book|title=2nd edition|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511711985|last1=Huybrechts|first1=Daniel|last2=Lehn|first2=Manfred|isbn=9780511711985}}

'''Luc Illusie''' ({{IPA-fr|ilyzi|lang}}; born 1940)<ref name="CNRS-Le-journal">{{cite web|url=https://lejournal.cnrs.fr/auteurs/luc-illusie|title=Luc Illusie. Mathématicien|website=CNRS Le journal|access-date=27 July 2016}}</ref> is a French mathematician, specializing in algebraic geometry. His most important work concerns the theory of the cotangent complex and deformations, [[crystalline cohomology]] and the De Rham–Witt complex, and logarithmic geometry.<ref name="CNRS-Le-journal"/> In 2012, he was awarded the Émile Picard Medal of the French Academy of Sciences.

==Biography==
Luc Illusie entered the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in 1959. At first a student of the mathematician [[Henri Cartan]], he participated in the Cartan–Schwartz seminar of 1963–1964. In 1964, following Cartan’s advice, he began to work with [[Alexandre Grothendieck]], collaborating with him on two volumes of the latter’s [[Séminaire de Géométrie Algébrique du Bois Marie]]. In 1970,  Illusie introduced the concept of the [[cotangent complex]].

A researcher in the [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique]] from 1964 to 1976, Illusie then became a professor at the [[University of Paris-Sud]], retiring as emeritus professor in 2005.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.math.u-psud.fr/~illusie/| title=Luc Illusie| access-date=27 July 2016| website=Mathematics Department, Université Paris-Sud}}</ref> Between 1984 and 1995, he was the director of the arithmetic and algebraic geometry group in the department of mathematics of that university. {{Interlanguage link multi|Torsten Ekedahl|sv}} and [[Gérard Laumon]] are among his students.

==Thesis==

In May 1971, Illusie defended a [[doctorate|state doctorate]] ({{Fr icon}} Thèse d’État) entitled "Cotangent complex; application to the theory of deformations" at the  [[University of Paris-Sud]], in front of a  jury composed of 
[[Alexander Grothendieck]],  [[Michel Demazure]] and [[Jean-Pierre Serre]] and presided by [[Henri Paul Cartan|Henri Cartan]].<ref name="Complexe-cotangent_35-pages">{{cite web |url=http://sites.mathdoc.fr/PMO/PDF/I_ILLUSIE-64.pdf |first=Luc |last=Illusie |title=Complexe cotangent; application à la théorie des déformations, Thèses présentées au Centre d'Orsay de l'Université Paris-Sud pour obtenir le grade de docteur es-sciences [Orsay – Série A, n° 749], Publications mathématiques d'Orsay 23, Bibliothèque de la Faculté des sciences Mathématique, 20415| year=1971}}</ref>

The thesis was published in French by [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer-Verlag]] as a two-volume book (in 1971<ref name="Complexe-cotangent1_XV-360-pages">{{cite book| first=Luc |last=Illusie| doi=10.1007/BFb0059052| title=Complexe Cotangent et Déformations I |volume=239|location=Berlin, Heidelberg, New York| publisher=Springer-Verlag| edition=First| series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics|issn=0075-8434|page=239| isbn=978-3-540-37001-7| year=1971}}</ref> & 1972<ref name="Complexe-cotangent2_304-pages">{{cite book| first=Luc |last=Illusie| doi=10.1007/BFb0059052| title=Complexe Cotangent et Déformations II |volume=239|location=Berlin, Heidelberg, New York| publisher=Springer-Verlag| edition=First| series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics|issn=0075-8434|pages=283| isbn=978-3-540-37962-1| year=1972}}</ref>). The main results of the thesis are summarized in a paper in English (entitled "Cotangent complex and Deformations of torsors and group schemes") presented in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], at [[Dalhousie University]], on January 1971 as part of a colloquium on algebraic geometry.<ref name="Complexe-cotangent_35-pages" /> This paper, originally published by [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer-Verlag]] in 1972,<ref name="Cotangent-complex_32-pages">{{cite encyclopedia |last=Illusie |first=Luc |author-link=Luc Illusie |editor1-last=Lawvere |editor1-first=F. William |editor1-link=William Lawvere|encyclopedia=Toposes, Algebraic Geometry and Logic |date=1972 |publisher=Springer |location=Berlin, Heidelberg, New York| series=Lecture Notes in Mathematics |volume=274 |doi=10.1007/BFb0073969|isbn= 978-3-540-37609-5 |pages=159–189|title=Toposes, Algebraic Geometry and Logic: Dalhousie University, Halifax, January 16-19, 1971 |chapter=Cotangent complex and deformations of torsors and group schemes }}</ref> also exists in a slightly extended version.<ref name="Complexe-cotangent_35-pages" />

Illusie's construction of the [[cotangent complex]] generalizes that of Michel André<ref>{{cite book|last1=André|first1=Michel|title=Homologie des algèbres commutatives|date=1974|publisher=Springer-Verlag|page=287}}</ref> and [[Daniel Quillen]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Quillen|first1=Daniel|title=On the (co)-homology of commutative rings|journal=Proceedings of Symposia in Pure Mathematics|date=1970|volume=17|pages=65–87}}</ref> to morphisms of [[topos#Ringed topoi|ringed topoi]]. The generality of the framework makes it possible to apply the formalism to
various first-order [[deformation theory|deformation problems]]: [[Scheme (mathematics)|schemes]], [[morphism of schemes|morphisms of schemes]],
[[group scheme]]s and [[Torsor (algebraic geometry)|torsors]] under group schemes. Results concerning commutative
group schemes in particular were the key tool in Grothendieck's proof of his
existence and structure theorem for infinitesimal deformations of [[Barsotti–Tate group]]s,<ref name="Mordell">{{cite journal|last1=Illusie|first1=Luc|title=Déformations de groupes de Barsotti–Tate (d'après A. Grothendieck)|journal=Seminar on Arithmetic Bundles: The Mordell Conjecture (Paris, 1983/84). Astérisque|date=1985|volume=127|pages=151–198}}</ref> an ingredient in [[Gerd Faltings]]' proof of the [[Mordell conjecture]].  In Chapter VIII of the second volume of the thesis, Illusie introduces
and studies derived [[de Rham cohomology|de Rham]] complexes.

==Awards==
Illusie has received the Langevin Prize of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] in 1977 and, in 2012, the [[Émile Picard Medal]] of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] for "his fundamental work on the [[cotangent complex]], the [[Picard–Lefschetz theory|Picard–Lefschetz formula]], [[Hodge theory]] and [[Log structure|logarithmic]] geometry".<ref name="Picard-medal">{{cite web|url=http://www.academie-sciences.fr/archivage_site/activite/prix/laureat_picard.pdf|title=Médaille Émile Picard (Mathématique): lauréats – Prix de l'Académie des sciences|website=[[French Academy of Sciences]]|date=3 October 2012|access-date=27 July 2016}}</ref>

'''Shihoko Ishii''' ({{lang-ja|石井志保子}}, born 1950)<ref>Birth year from [http://www.isni.org/isni/0000000440063831 ISNI authority control file], retrieved 2018-11-28.</ref> is a Japanese mathematician and professor at the [[University of Tokyo]].  Her research area is [[algebraic geometry]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ishii, Shihoko|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=198021|website=MathSciNet|publisher=Mathematical Reviews|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref>

==Education==

Ishii received her bachelor's degree from [[Tokyo Women's Christian University]] in 1973 and her master's degree from [[Waseda University]] in 1975.  She earned her PhD from [[Tokyo Metropolitan University]] in 1983.<ref name="europeansociety">{{cite web|title=Shihoko Ishii|url=http://www.europeanwomeninmaths.org/women-in-math/portrait/shihoko-ishii|website=European Women in Mathematics|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref>

==Research==

Ishii's research focuses on [[singularity theory]].  She studies arc spaces, a mathematical concept related to [[Jet (mathematics)|jets]]: arc spaces are [[algebraic variety|varieties]] encapsulating information about curves on another variety.<ref name="europeansociety" />

==Awards and honours==

Ishii received the [[Saruhashi Prize]] for accomplishments by a Japanese woman researcher in the natural sciences in 1995.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Sumiko Otsubo|chapter=Women Scientists and Gender Ideology|editor1-last=Robertson|editor1-first=Jennifer|title=A Companion to the Anthropology of Japan|date=2008|page=474}}</ref>  As a postdoc, Ishii was inspired by reading a profile of [[Fumiko Yonezawa]], a physicist and former winner of the Saruhashi prize.<ref name="europeansociety" />

Ishii received the Algebra Prize from the [[Mathematical Society of Japan]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Prizes by Research Sections|url=http://mathsoc.jp/en/pamph/current/section_pr.html|website=Mathematical Society of Japan|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref>
